channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #64 - Is Mojolicious anti-CPAN or is it a gateway-drug?
item.description:
Hi,

I am back from Budapest, but this was a very difficult week for me. A dear friend of mine in Transylvania - EnikÅ‘ Becsey-Imreh - has suddenly passed away. May she rest in peace.

For the rest of us, there are the Perl articles:

item.title: Alien::Base Beta Release!
item.description: The Alien::* modules make it easy to install external (non-CPAN) dependencies in a CPAN module. That usually makes the life of the user easier, but creating Alien modules was hard. The Alien::Base module should make it much easier for the developer. Go ahead, test it.

item.title: TWiki-5.1.2 Released: Rock Solid. Usable. Fun.
item.description: TWiki is an open source wiki application development platform written in Perl.

item.title: Why LedgerSMB uses Moose. An intro for PostgreSQL folks
item.description: The article starts off by describing the major sources of bugs in any application, and then explains how using Moose can eliminate some of them. The comparison to SQL data safety is an interesting way to show Moose. (BTW, this article is a few months old, I just misplaced it back then.)

item.title: My hiring principles
item.description: Do you want to get hired by Andrew Shitov? First make sure you have a picture with Larry Wall. Then read the article for further clues.

item.title: Please Don't Write Snowflake Code
item.description: So what do you say, should Perl projects have a standard style? Should they pick one from several standard styles? Is it OK to use your personal coding style in an Open source project? What about within a company?

item.title: Thoughts on a Catalyst Roadmap
item.description: After running the Catalyst poll, John Napiorkowski is now discussing what is Catalyst and where it is going? He explains what a 'Product Statement' is, in a way that hopefully can bridge the gap between the technology oriented people and the marketing oriented people and connects that idea to the road-map.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - September 2012 - Listen Like Thieves
item.description: Several entries, let me point out two: Brian Cassidy is making progress checking if the Changes file in every distribution is according to the 'standard', and Neil Bowers asked how to get more test reports on 'development releases' of CPAN modules.

item.title: Perl DBD::ODBC 1.40_3 released to the CPAN
Citrus Perl 5.16.1 Updated
item.description: Citrus Perl is a Perl distribution for Linux, Windows and Mac that already contains Wx to make it easy to develop desktop applications.

item.title: A concise forking idiom in pure Perl
item.description: Aristotle Pagaltzis is the maintainer of Proc::Fork, but for the regular cases he recommends a construct that does not use that module.

item.title: A little 'state' idiom
item.description: Aristotle Pagaltzis shows how to ask 'have I been here?' in Perl.

item.title: Mojolicious: an unexpected result
item.description: The original article by Ovid in which he suggests that companies using the Mojolicious (with its no-CPAN-dependency policy) tend to be avoid using CPAN and tend to reinvent the rest of the wheels themselves. As I can tell, Ovid does not say which is the cause and which is the result.

item.title: Counter-productive over time
item.description: In his response, Sawyer explains why he dislikes the idea of no-dependency. How, he thinks, it strengthens the 'Don't use CPAN here' policy of some companies.

item.title: Why People Don't Like Mojolicious
item.description: In his analysis, Joel Berger first covers a few reasons why people might dislike Mojolicious, but then he takes the opposite stand. He thinks that Mojolicious acts like a gateway-drug. The thing that can handed to people (and companies) that are afraid of CPAN. Once they tasted it and liked it you can now offer them more CPAN modules.

item.title: Grant Extension Request - Improving Perl 5
item.description: Nicholas Clark asks for another $20,000 to work 400 hours on perl. ($50/hour)

item.title: Fine-Tuning the 'vim-project' Plugin For My Perl Needs
item.description: A story in which Yanick Champoux almost created an IDE based on vim.

item.title: Parsing STEP
item.description: STEP is a format of CAD files aka. ISO-10303. Solomon Foster uses the grammar extension capabilities of Perl 6 to be able to build a strict parser that will enforce the standard, and one, that can also parse real-world, not so standard files.

item.title: Preliminary results - Survey about Newcomer experience in Perl + One week reminder
I'll be speaking at 'We Actually Build Stuff'
item.description: Jonathan Worthington is going to Lithuania to talk about his work on the Rakudo Perl 6 compiler. (30th November 2012)

item.title: Perl booth at T-Dose
item.description: The Technical Dutch Open Source Event (T-Dose) will be held on 27-28 October, 2012. There is going the be a Perl booth, probably with a lot of books and an almost real-life sized camel.

item.title: YAPC::Brasil 2012
item.description: October 19-20, 2012, Sao Paulo, Brasil

item.title: Austria Perl Workshop
item.description: November 16-17, 2012, Vienna, Austria

item.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW)
item.description: November 24, 2012, London, UK

item.title: OSDC Australia
item.description: December 4-7, 2012, Sydney, Australia
